me is that of course like everything it depends on what you're doing but in my experience when it comes to backend
development and and application development the unit tests ends up being
very very brittle because they they test inner workings of your application and
the things that you're actually trying to keep stable are the interfaces to your users and between parts of the
system so when you actually test those and you test the behavior of your boundaries that is when you can actually
reason about correctness that matches like your users and of course if you're
writing a mathematical function or a pure function then those are the same and unit tests make sense because you
define correctness in terms of inputs and outputs to that function but when you're creating a system you reason
about correctness in terms of the work that that system is performing and by
writing tests at that level you end up with tests that they don't break every
time you refactor something and if you do refactor something and you do it correctly those tests will just keep on
passing in the same way that if you refactor the internals of a mathematical function the unit tests will keep
passing so if you're supposed to write few unit tests what would be an example of a unit test worth writing so I think
everything you do is is different but generally unit tests are great when you're dealing with a function that has
